translated: Records of the Three Treasures Through the Ages, Volume 4, Translation of Scriptures, Chapter 4, Translation of Scriptures, Later Han Dynasty
Submitted by the Imperial Secretary Fei Changfang, Scholar of the Tripiá¹­aka Translation Office, in the 17th year of the Kaihuang era
(Later Han) The records of the Later Han Dynasty. Emperor Guangwu's fourth son, Zhuang, succeeded to the throne and was posthumously titled Emperor Xiao
Ming.
In the seventh year of Yongping, he dreamed at night of a golden man sixteen feet tall,
with a sun-shaped disc on his neck, flying through the air and arriving.
The light was dazzling and illuminated the palace courtyard.
In the morning, he gathered the ministers and ordered them to interpret the dream.
The erudite Fu Yi advanced and presented his interpretation, saying:
Your subject has heard that in the West there is a deity called the Buddha.
Is it possible that what Your Majesty saw was him?
The Emperor considered it to be so.
He joyfully accepted the auspicious omen and dispatched envoys.
Qin Jing, a Gentleman-in-Attendance, and Wang Zun, a student of the Imperial Academy, and fourteen others,
were sent to India.
In the country of Yuezhi, they met with KÄÅ›yapa MÄtanga.
They obtained forty-two chapters of Buddhist scriptures and also obtained a painted image.
He returned to Luoyang on a white horse.
He then built a monastery named White Horse Temple.
Monasteries in various states competed to establish in gratitude for the white horse's merit.
More than two hundred steps to the left of Qingmen Road in the old city of Chang'an, to the right of Zhongxing Temple,
is the remaining foundation of White Horse Temple.
He then translated the Sutra in Forty-two Sections.
It was sealed in the stone chamber of the Lantai Pavilion.
Since then, the teachings of ÅšÄkyamuni have continued to flourish like clouds.
Åšramaá¹‡as and faithful laypeople have successively transmitted and translated.
In the time of Emperor Huan of the Han, golden and silver Buddha images were also made.
In the third year of Guanghe of Emperor Ling of the Han,
he sent a senior official to the Buddha's pagoda and temple in Luoyang.
To offer food to the Å›ramaá¹‡as.
Hanging silk, burning incense, scattering flowers, and lighting lamps.
In the seventh year of Guanghe,
Zhang Jiao and others plotted to kill their rebellious party, both inside and outside their relatives.
All matters related to Laozi, witchcraft, and divination were abolished.
Those who upheld the five precepts of Buddhism were not to be seated.
In the Qin dynasty, the monk Shi Lifan.
And from the time when Liu Xiang of the Eastern Han Dynasty collated books in the Imperial Library,
Up to this point, there were established records.
The sutras began with the Forty-two Chapters.
The person was KÄÅ›yapa MÄtanga, the earliest.
Up to the end of the Jian'an era of the Han Emperor Xian.
In between, one hundred and fifty-two years.
Spanning eleven rulers.
Twelve people, both Chinese and foreign, monks and laypeople.
Combined with the old remains, further supplementing the previous omissions.
All ancient lost translations.
A total of three hundred fifty-nine sutras and vinayas were compiled.
Four hundred and twenty-seven scrolls.
As the record of the Later Han Dynasty, it is circulated in this scroll.
Hopefully, those who peruse it will examine the ancient and modern times.
The scattered and gathered scriptures of different eras.
The flourishing Dharma treasures are clearly displayed.

The Sutra in Forty-two Sections by KÄÅ›yapa MÄtanga, in 1 fascicle. This sÅ«tra in 1 fascicle was translated during the reign of Emperor Ming by the brÄhman monk KÄÅ›yapa MÄtanga from Central India.ğŸ”½Some say it was Zhu Shemo Teng.
Some simply say Shemo Teng.
The various records differ, and it is not known which is correct.
Since it was not yet known which were the surnames and which were the names,
it had not been translated before, so it was fully revealed.
Zhizang was intelligent and had an elegant demeanor from a young age.
He was knowledgeable and learned.
He was especially proficient in the sutras and precepts.
His thoughts were sharp and penetrating.
He explored the profound and subtle.
Whenever he expounded the text and analyzed the principles, there were always new meanings.
The students at that time did not follow him.
The Dharma Master traveled to India.
In the northwest, there was a small country.
The country revered and followed him.
Soon, a neighboring country raised troops.
The weapons of war were not put away.
It was about to invade the territory, but there were always obstacles.
Therefore, they suspected there were extraordinary techniques.
They secretly sent spies to observe.
The messenger returned and said:
The ruler and ministers of that country study and practice the Mahayana sutras such as the Golden Light Sutra.
The sutra says:
The earth spirit kings protect the place where this Dharma is spoken.
For this reason, the neighboring country asked for peace and sought the Dharma to widely spread the Mahayana.
Since then, it has gradually spread here in the south.
In the Yongping years, he followed Cai Yin to Luoyang.
At Baima Temple, he translated this sutra.
Based on the records, it was compiled.
It is the ancestor of sutras in China.
The old records say:
It was originally an excerpt from a foreign sutra.
It was originally from a large collection.
It summarizes the essentials and draws on worldly customs, resembling the 18 chapters of the Xiaojing.
Dao An's records do not mention its origin.
The old records and Zhu Shixing's Han Dynasty records and Seng You's Record of the Collection of the Tripiá¹­aka.
It is also recorded, but because the great Dharma was first transmitted and people did not yet have faith, it caused Ma Teng to keep his profound understanding to himself and not translate much more.
Later he died in Luoyang.
The details are recorded in Zhu Shixing's Han Dynasty records and the biographies of eminent monks and miscellaneous records.
Bao Chang also says:
This was translated by Zhu Faxian.
This may be based on the fact that he came at the same time as Kang Senghui.

These five works total sixteen fascicles.
Åšramaá¹‡a Dharmaraká¹£a of Central India.
He was intelligent and elegant from a young age, widely interested and knowledgeable.
He thoroughly understood meditation and the Vinaya.
He recited over a million words of sÅ«tras.
He had over a thousand disciples.
He did not seek comfort in his dwelling but always had the intention to greatly benefit others.
His precepts and conduct were strict, and the assembly could not fathom him.
He heard that the Han envoy Yan had come to inquire about Buddhism in China.
He then had the intention to travel lightly.
The king of his country did not allow it.
He secretly came with An Shigao.
He arrived later.
In the time of Emperor Ming, he first translated the Sutra in Forty-two Sections together with An Shigao.
An Shigao passed away.
Dharmaraká¹£a translated it himself.
In the past, Emperor Wu of the Han Dynasty dug Kunming Pool.
At the bottom, he found ashes and soot.
He asked Dongfang Shuo.
Shuo said,
You can ask the Brahmins from the Western Regions.
When Dharmaraksa arrived,
he was then asked about it.
Dharmaraksa said,
This is the ash from the conflagration at the end of the eon.
Shuo's words were verified.
Many people believed it.
Furthermore, when Qin Jing returned from Yuezhi, he obtained
the model drawing of the sandalwood image of King Udayana, which came to Luoyang.
The Emperor immediately ordered it to be copied and worshipped.
Since then, the spread of the painted image has continued to the present.

As for the old translation Hu parinirvÄá¹‡a,
The meaning of the word Hu is not yet clear.
Carefully observing the scriptures that have come down from ancient times, the wise and virtuous ones recorded them.
Whenever they translated, they always said translating Hu into Han.
Hu is a border region of the Western Regions.
Han is the Eastern Land.
One name is simply called Tianzhu in the Western Regions. Therefore, the Book of Han says Shendu country. Shendu is Tianzhu.
There is Central Tianzhu,
which is the land of Tianzhu where the Buddha was born.
There is east, west, south, and north.
Therefore, it is called the Five Heavens.
Those Five Heavens look at this Eastern Land and generally call it Zhina.
Sometimes it is called Zhenyan or Zhenda.
This is simply taking the sound with Chu and Xia differences.
If it should be called Han,
Han only refers to the Liu clan.
The two dynasties of Former Han and Later Han are called by one name.
Later Han abdicated to Wei.
The Wei Dynasty was weak and divided into Wu and Shu.
Although Wei swallowed Shu, it still returned to cede to Jin.
Since Jin took control, the nine provinces were divided into different territories.
The places where the scriptures were translated were different, so the translations were not the same.
It is necessary to rely on the titles of the emperors to distinguish them.
Now, for this record, I have all relied on the correct ones.
Moreover, since the Hu people are the border barbarians of the Western Regions,
they are similar to the Di, Qiang, Man, Yi, and Yao tribes.
How can they have scriptures?
Yet it is said that the Hu language is the original.
Who is to blame for this model of the secular world?
The Buddha was born in India.
In that land, the brahmin caste is generally called Brahma.
Brahma means pure and is descended from the Ä€bhÄsvara Heaven.
The Ä€bhÄsvara Heaven is the lowest of the Brahma heavens.
At the beginning of the kalpa, the water dried up, the earth solidified, and they ate the earth's fat.
Their bodies became coarse and heavy, unable to fly away.
Thus, people were born.
Because of their ancestral origins, they are called Brahma.
Therefore, the Sanskrit language and Sanskrit writing should be used.
The translators of the sutras in Chinese had not shaved their heads yet.
Zhu Shixing of the Wei dynasty was the first to renounce the world and follow the Dharma, but he was still called by his secular surname.
The Wu and Jin dynasties followed suit and did not change this custom.
From the Fu Qin dynasty onwards, there was Shi Da'an.
He was unique in his time and had a profound understanding.
Monks and laypeople admired him like rice and hemp.
Since he shaved his head and succeeded the Shakyamuni lineage, but had a different surname, how could he be considered a descendant?
Now that one has renounced the world, they should all be called Shakyamuni.
Later, when the four Agamas were translated,
the text indeed said:
The four castes who have renounced the world are of the same Shakyamuni lineage.
The assembly all marveled and submitted. The four castes are:
1. Kshatriya, the royal caste.
2. Brahmin, the caste of high-ranking practitioners.
3. Vaishya, the caste of farmers and commoners in this land.
4. Shudra, the lowest caste.
In this way, it is like a black slave. It is appropriate for the Jin and Qin dynasties.
The catalog of revised texts deletes annotations from various scriptures.
He calls himself the model of the sky, a standard for later generations.

A total of 148 volumes.
All are the records of the Tripiá¹­aka Master Seng You's compilation of the ancient and old two catalogs.
And the sources lost by Dao An, as well as the lost translations newly collected.
The volumes of various scriptures are very extensive.
The titles of the collated scriptures are numerous and corrupt.
The exchanges and interactions are truly difficult to determine.
Without seeing the scriptures, one only reads the titles.
Some have sources, some have no translations.

Examining their origins, they are not without reasons, but since they have passed through many years, they are attached to this end.ğŸ”½Hoping that later scholars will, if they encounter the original sources,
Reconsider them as having a basis and clarify them.
Purify the Dharma ocean and make the waves still.
